greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Multiplicative with a(2^e) = 1 and a(p^e) = prevprime(p)^e for odd primes p.
comment: a(A003961(n)) = n for all n. [This is a left inverse function for the injection A003961.]
Bisections are A064216 (the terms at odd indices) and A064989 itself (the terms at even indices), i.e., a(2n) = a(n) for all n.

When n represents an unordered integer partition via the indices of primes present in its prime factorization (for n >= 2, n corresponds to the partition given as the n-th row of A112798) this operation subtracts one from each part. If n is of the form 2^k (a partition having just k 1's as its parts) the result is an empty partition (which is encoded by 1, having an "empty" factorization).
For all odd numbers n >= 3, a(n) tells which number is located immediately above n in square array A246278. Cf. also A246277.

Alternatively, if numbers are represented as the multiset of indices of prime factors with multiplicity, this operation subtracts 1 from each element and discards the 0's. - _M. F. Hasler_, Dec 29 2014
link: Harry J. Smith (first 1000 terms) & Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: If n = product A000040(k)^e(k) then a(n) = product A008578(k)^e(k) [where A000040(n) gives the n-th prime, and A008578(n) gives 1 for 1 and otherwise the (n-1)-th prime].
a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = A008578(A055396(n)) * a(A032742(n)). [Above formula represented as a recurrence. Cf. A252461.]
a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = A008578(A061395(n)) * a(A052126(n)). [Compare to the formula of A252462.]
This prime-shift operation is used in the definitions of many other sequences, thus it can be expressed in many alternative ways:
a(n) = A122111(A122111(n)/A105560(n)) = A122111(A052126(A122111(n))). [In A112798-partition context: conjugate, remove the largest part (the largest prime factor), and conjugate again.]
a(n) = A249818(A250470(A249817(n))). [A250470 is an analogous operation for "going one step up" in the square array A083221 (A083140).]
Product_{k=1..n} a(k) = n! / A307035(n). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 21 2019
maple: q:= proc(p) prevprime(p) end proc: q(2):= 1:
mathematica: Table[Times @@ Power[Which[# == 1, 1, # == 2, 1, True, NextPrime[#, -1]] & /@ First@ #, Last@ #] &@ Transpose@ FactorInteger@ n, {n, 81}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jan 04 2016 *)
program: (MIT/GNU Scheme, with Aubrey Jaffer's SLIB Scheme library)
(define (A064989 n) (if (= 1 n) n (apply * (map (lambda (k) (if (zero? k) 1 (A000040 k))) (map -1+ (map A049084 (factor n)))))))
(definec (A064989 n) (if (= 1 n) n (* (A008578 (A055396 n)) (A064989 (A032742 n))))) ;; One based on given recurrence and utilizing memoizing definec-macro.

(definec (A064989 n) (cond ((= 1 n) n) ((even? n) (A064989 (/ n 2))) (else (A163511 (/ (- (A243071 n) 1) 2))))) ;; Corresponds to one of the alternative formulas, but is very unpractical way to compute this sequence. - _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 18 2014

(PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, f=factor(n)~; a=1; j=1; if (n>1 && f[1, 1]==2, j=2); for (i=j, length(f), a*=precprime(f[1, i] - 1)^f[2, i]); write("b064989.txt", n, " ", a) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Oct 02 2009
(PARI) a(n) = {my(f = factor(n)); for (i=1, #f~, if ((p=f[i,1]) % 2, f[i,1] = precprime(p-1), f[i,1] = 1);); factorback(f);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Dec 18 2014
return 1 if n==1 else reduce(mul, [1 if i==2 else prevprime(i)**f[i] for i in f])
print [a(n) for n in range(1, 101)] # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jun 15 2017
xref: Similar prime-shifts towards smaller numbers: A252461, A252462, A252463.
results.author: _Vladeta Jovovic_, Oct 30 2001
